Ang definition ng fake news ay maliwanag na pag ikaw ang tinatamaan ng mga social media comments and attack sa inyo ay fake news ito. Majority posted in social media are merely responses from viewers and readers from all walks of life. Ang fake news are very simple to figure out. government officials are the target of news media to get fresh info for any breaking news and this is where the news start to leak out. Who started the revelation or who throw punches to other side becomes the creator of the news. Here comes the news media and the social media to air on tv and radio what they got. So we the viewer are merely the wave of your news whether fake or real. When it reaches the end definitely it returns back to you with counter punches. If you hit us hard we hit you harder. That’s it.
When you say something in public and telling fantasy, not real it becomes a dark shadow in their mind. Telling something concrete solid and proven facts are welcome but not like a weaked witch cursing you will have a dark future.

MY INITIAL OPINION ON FACEBOOK'S LAUNCHING OF THIRD-PARTY FACT CHECKING PROGRAM

This Facebook crack down of "fake news" (which by the way, there is no such thing from a journalistic standpoint) on its very platform should first distinguish the difference between a news & a commentary/
opinions!

If the supposed 'news' contains untruthful & non-factual/
false information rendering the the supposed 'reportage' a false story, then yes, it should not be allowed to be posted on Facebook.

On the other hand, commentaries/
opinions should not be banned on Facebook for one single reason - it violates freedom of expression!

If the commentary/
opinion writer oversteps the boundary, then the writer can always be sued for his written pieces!

#ParaSaBayan #ProPH #SupportPH

Metadata can be created manually, or by automated information processing. Manual creation tends to be more accurate, allowing the user to input any information they feel is relevant or needed to help describe the file. Automated metadata creation can be much more elementary, usually only displaying information such as file size, file extension, when the file was created and who created the file.

A CALL FOR HUMILITY AND REPENTANCE

“When you spread out your hands, I will hide My eyes from you;
Even though you make many prayers, I will not hear.
Your hands are full of blood.” (Isaiah 1:15)

It does not even make any distinction of whether enemy’s or criminal’s blood. Thus, we cannot rationalize that it is okay to shed an enemy’s or criminal’s blood. The verse says blood, any human blood.

In 1 Chronicles 22:8 God told David “You have shed much blood and have fought many wars. You are not to build a house for my Name, because you have shed much blood on the earth in my sight.” The blood on David’s hands was “legitimate” as the blood of enemies of Israel in war. Yet still God saw it as unrighteous. What more if it was the blood of his own people like what is happening in our country today? There is no justification for killing people, even “criminals” especially when there is no death penalty in effect in the land. And to believe that more than several hundred were killed (some of them old and minors, and some already in handcuffs) because they allegedly fought back is naïve, and a mockery of God’s word.

King David wrote that in order for him to be heard he has to approach God in utter humility, with “a broken spirit; a broken and contrite heart” (Psalm 51:17). Not a spirit of defiance, arrogance and utter disregard of human life, no matter how ‘criminal’ that life may be.

President Duterte must do the same. Yet, rather than being contrite and humble, he continues to spit out profanity and arrogance insulting world leaders and threatening his own people. And those who support him continue to bash and berate those who criticize him. The arrogance and animosity in our land is destroying us from within. If this continues long enough, we do not need an outside invader to destroy us. We will self-destruct.

Just because a leader was chosen by a plurality of the people does not mean that leader is anointed by God to lead. "They set up kings, but not by Me; They made princes, but I did not acknowledge them." (Hosea 8:4)

It is not a prayer for Davao that we need. It is a prayer for humility to admit that the President is wrong and that 16 million of us were wrong and as a nation ask forgiveness from God for choosing a leader who has publicly mocked God (http://
news.abs-cbn.com

nation/06/04/15/

Then perhaps, then and only then will God act with mercy and break our national arrogance and defiance of His Word, and rectify our error, grant humility and wisdom to the President and FINALLY ANOINT HIM AS LEADER, and heal our land.

Until then, even a hundred million prayers will not suffice, and God’s hand will continue to be heavy against the President and our country.

2 Chron. 7:14, promises forgiveness, "if my people who are called by my name HUMBLE THEMSELVES, PRAY, SEEK MY FACE, AND TURN FROM THEIR WICKED WAYS, then I will hear from heaven, and will forgive their sin and heal their land.”

On the other hand...
“It is a dreadful thing to fall into the hands of the living God.” Hebrews 10:31

1. Why God allowed President Duterte to win and lead the Philippines despite of his bad mouth, broken marriage/
infidelity, aggresiveness so on and so forth?!?!!!

2. Why some of the Christians are supporting this kind of President? "Ungodly President"?!?

3. Why all of a sudden the International media and the world rather the UNIVERSE are all eyes in our beloved country, PHILIPPINES 🇵🇭?!? We received a lot of criticisms here and there.

Let me answer these questions based on my point of view. These are my thoughts and opinions (i am free to say anything on my wall, whether you agree or not, i dont mind! I just want to express my two cents here✌🏻️😉)

1. In the bible, during the Old and New Testament, there were bad rulers and kings that was destined to lead the countries. Actually, really bad kings compare to our present President. God allows good, bad, young, old, wise, etc... rulers and kings in order to fulfill his plans and purpose for the nation. God is sovereign and he knows what he is doing. Overall, God is in control!

2. As a Christian, I am supporting President Duterte simply because he was the ordained leader of our country. It is our duty as a fellow Filipino to support our President whether we like Pres. Duterte or not. (Support the good things for the sake of our nation). YES, I know and I agree that we have a freedom of speech, freedom to choose, freedom to do legal things because we are in a democratic country. Despite of his bad words most of the time, which I can say I dont LIKE at all but for me I accepted the fact that he is like that and the words does not define him as a whole. Each one of us has his/her own unique character and personality and so with our President. Every one has always a room for mistakes in order for us to be corrected, learn and grow and so with our President.

On the other hand, I realized what if Pres. Duterte did not win. What if Roxas, Robredo, Binay, etc... Do you think their personalities can handle such issues in a serious way (i mean really work and focus on it) such as war on drugs which is really a deep and serious problem of the society (locally and internationally
). That's why we need a President who is really TOUGH!

3. Because of DRUGS, it's too controversial to explain but because our President is very serious to eradicate the drugs, it will affect not only our country but also the whole world.

#justmyopinion

We are at the toes of the Daniel Prophecy.. where pur leaders are chosen by the people via election. And whoever was voted.. that is a lawful authority chosen by God to rule over us. This is what we call God's Permission. And that is also very valid. God can always choose to raise a perfect candidate, but that is not God's job, because in our chosen system.. choosing a candidate is electorate's job. What the majority of the people wanted... that will be the leader. Our current president is a reflection of the heart of the 16 million Filipino electorate. For God to annul that will not make God unjust under the bar of justice in Heaven (unless believers in Christ pray to give Philippines a godly, righteous, prudent, wise leader who is also a statesman. I the meantime, we pray for our leaders, whether they won the election, or who unjustly ascended to the throne, submitting to them as unto the Lord. This is also true for those who assumed authority by illegal means. As born again believers in Christ, we are all under a Kingdom.. whose King is none other than Jesus, whose power, edicts are final and executory.. abd can never be broken. Sometimes unjust leaderswill rise to power with God's permission, because no believers are serious enough in praying for a godly leadership. Churches promote their own candidates rather than pray for the righteous leadership. With lack of prayer, this creates no other choice for God but to release a leader who is not the solution to the nations' needs at that time. After their assumption to power.. whether legally or illegally, Heaven's verdict is already final and executory.. and God only intervenes when someone would pray.

So I enjoin everyone to pray to God (in Jesus name)for our current leaders, so that God's will of righteousness, blessing, healing, success of our country in both and international relations will be guaranteed. Jesus is the Lord of all government..

MY COMMENTARY

Why are we undergoing an extremely different transition from one president to another? What will be the end result?

1. In our 71 years of being independent, this is the first time we have a president who is not like the rest. He is genuinely pro-poor and was elected by the people without the support of traditional politicians and self serving businessmen. He also happens to be a lawyer.

2. Some people are afraid that because of PRRD's political will and genuine desire to improve our country's plight, the oligarchs may be displaced. The traditional politicians' shenanigans may be uncovered. The narco generals and their lieutenants and the narco politicians may be unmasked. The gambling lords may lose their business. All of them run the risk of ending up in jail and/or losing their riches. THUS, WE ARE WITNESSING THE ATTEMPTS TO TOPPLE HIM DOWN BY DISCREDITING HIM AMONG THE PILIPINOS AND OTHER NATIONS IN THE HOPE THAT HE MAY BE PRESSURED TO STEP DOWN.

3. PRRD is not the typical president who had to horse trade to win. Thus, he has a free hand to do as he deems best for the Philippines. This is the first time his supporters which run into the millions continue to involve themselves in the affairs of government and openly declare support for PRRD to the extent of using their own funds.

4. His cabinet is comprised mostly of septuagenarians
, where money is no longer the main objective, but to leave legacies behind.

5. He touched base with the poor specially the leftists such that for the first time, his SONA was not picketed but supported by the masses.

6. PRRD is tough and walks his talk. He and his selected men cannot be bribed. Therefore, the crooked and the rich are no longer within their comfort zones.

7. It's a total turnaround from the class of past presidents we have had who were politically and financially indebted during their respective campaigns, thus the impossibility of not returning favors which is the root of corruption.

8. PRRD's style of management is very unorthodox. He doesn't care what people say about him so long as he is able to deliver on his promises and fix what is broken in our nation.

9. He cannot be impeached because under the present constitution, only the Lower House which overwhelmingly supports him, can initiate impeachment proceedings. Then it is the Senate, majority of whose members back him up, that will be the judge of the impeachment trial.

10. So the battleground is in media, the Senate and Lower House inquiries which serve only the purpose of being venues for political offense and defense. What we are undergoing is a perception war.

The media in general (local and foreign), through orders and financing from his enemies, are portraying a scenario where all drug related killings are attributable to PRRD. This is unfair. We have 4 types of killings:
a) legitimate police operations
b) hired killers who eliminate drug pushers and users who have information that may lead to pinpointing their colleagues and superiors (as much P100k per head)
c) murders ordered by anti-PRRD people who wish to discredit his administration and paint a portrait of violence before the world, by exaggerating the manner of executions such as placing cardboards on the victims with the tag "Pusher ako. Huwag Tularan". Or taping the faces of those killers like mummies and dumping them in abandoned fields.
d) crooked policemen who eliminate those who can link them to the trade

These last 3 types are the genuine extrajudicial killings.
Do you honestly think legitimate PNP missions have time to stage these "dramas"? What for?

11. The latest yellow propaganda is that the war against drugs targets the poor. Gascon, an LP diehard, doesn't understand the structure of the marketing aspect of pushing drugs. Because of his self inflicted blindness to reality, he is not aware that the drug trade cannot generate billions of pesos if you do not sell using the poor. Besides, what percentage of our population comprises the poor and subsistence level of our economy?

12. Sec. Evasco revealed intelligence reports that some high ranking LP officers and Trillanes are contemplating a coup. But Evasco says it will fail as they do not have the military on their side. Word has it that the drug hierarchy does not end with Delima. More narco generals and narco politicians are plotting this coup for fear of being exposed and jailed. Let us wait and see.

CONCLUSION: For those of you who are trying to unseat PRRD by extra constitutional means, you will not succeed. As long as our president continues his battle to right what is wrong, to improve the lives of the impoverished, to eliminate life threatening drugs in order to save millions of lives, to destroy illegal gambling so that the government can have more funds in its coffers to uplift the common man's life, to foster peace after generations of rebellion, all of which will attract foreign investments and consequently create more jobs, you, the enemies of the state, will fail.#DuterteFight #PartnerForChang

ANG CALL SA CHURCH AY MANGUNA SA PAGTATANGHAL AT PAGTATATAG NG CHRISTIAN PUBLIC ETHICS
By Maria Lourdes Sereno
Napakasipag nating magturo ng Ten Commandments, ngunit hanggang panloob na aplikasyon lamang sa personal na buhay ng mga miyembro ng parokya o fellowship natin. “Huwag kukupit ni isang coupon bond sa opisina!” ang paalala natin sa kapatiran.
Parang may sobrang mali, na ang pinapansin natin ay mga ganoong pribado at maliliit na bagay, ngunit okay lang sa atin ang bilyon-bilyones
na pagnanakaw sa pamahalaan! Kahit sino pong observer, sasabihin, may malaking “damaged culture” o “inauthentic faith” ang mga Pilipino. Parang yung sinasabi ni Hesus na hindi Niya kilala ang workers of wickedness kahit pa tumatawag sila sa pangalan Niya. Iyun po ang maaaring malapit na description sa mga nag-iidolo pa rin sa mga magnanakaw sa gobyerno.
At paano po tayo nagiging workers of wickedness sa pagsuporta sa mga magnanakaw sa gobyerno? By calling evil good, at good as evil. Iyun ay condemned sa Isaiah 5:20. Ibig sabihin, sa isang naniniwala sa Diyos, ang masama ay masama, at hindi pinapalusot na okay lang ito.
Iyung pagtanghal sa mga pulitikong bilyon-bilyon ang ninakaw ay pagtawag ng kasamaan bilang kabutihan. At pag tinatawag na “rebelde” ang mga tao na humihingi ng pagtatapat o accountability sa mga opisyales, ay pagtawag sa kabutihang ginagawa nila, bilang kasamaan. Remember po, sa Isaiah 1:17, TO DO GOOD IS TO DO JUSTICE, and TO REBUKE THE OPPRESSOR! Ibig sabihin, when you call as evil those who are asking for accountability in government, you are participating in the works of wickedness. Obvious po, diba? Nananawagan na nga ang mabubuting miyembro ng simbahan na ibalik sa bayan ang nakaw na yaman, pinipigilan niyo pa?
Sinasabi po natin na Jesus came to redeem all of life (Romans 8:20-22). At inuulit pa natin ang Great Commission Niya to disciple all nations in His teachings (Matthew 28:19).
Kung ang lahat ng aspeto ng buhay ay ire-redeem ni Jesus, at ang discipleship ay sa buong bansa, eh di dapat ang simbahan ay ituro kung paano mamuhay ayon sa teachings ni Jesus ang pamahalaan. Bakit po natin hindi i-apply ang lahat ng ethical teachings natin sa mga nanunungkulan sa gobyerno? Wala dapat ni isang magnakaw. At ang magnanakaw, huwag iboboto. At iyung humahawak ng nakaw na yaman, dapat isauli ito kasi hindi naman sa kanila iyon, kundi sa taumbayan.
Tingnan niyo po ang maaaring magandang mangyayari. Hindi na tayo parang may schizophrenia o mala-halimaw na dalawang personalidad. Magkakaroon na tayo ng integridad at hindi gaya ngayon na nagdududa ang mga tao kung Kristyano nga ang maraming Pilipino.
Kailangan po, na ang lahat ng nagsasabing nagpapasakop sila kay Kristo ay manguna sa pagtatag ng standards, parang dekalogo ni Andres Bonifacio kumbaga, ng Christian Public Ethics. At dapat ito masimulang maituro sa ating mga tahanan, simbahan at sa mga paaralang bukas dito. Habulin natin ang kakulangan natin. Punuin po natin ang kauhawan ng bayan para sa integridad sa pamahalaan.

It "could be" a case like the one in Bible where...when the Israelites were clamoring to have a king...and just so people at that time realizes the results of what they were ardently seeking (ie. having a king or a change-of-syste
m from having just judges&prophets
...to having their very first king) ...God ALLOWED them to have their king....so that people would realize the result/
impact of what they were asking God. King Saul was the one allowed to be king but he did not do right as we read from the Bible. In our case at the present time, Filipinos were desperate to see CHANGE and majority (16M) thought Duterte was the one to initiate and build that change, so they voted for him. In my opinion, it could be again a case of "allowed by God" scenario ... to teach us something and hoping later Filipinos would realize what they asked for and who they voted for....until we reach to the point where we come to God again and ask deliverance from the consequences of the choices the 16M people have made and the mess we are into. King Saul lacked the character to become the rightful king but he was part of the story where God paved the way to introduce the King of kings, although it was a story of generation-to-generatio
n overhaul work for people-building
& nation-building
. So I'd like to imagine we could be in that "ground-level" rebuilding of the Philippines....
and we have yet to see the next layers of generation, where righteous leaders will be established by God, and eventually, we will witness a beautiful country as we have always dreamed the Philippines to be.

videos.description:
Peter Kairuz answers journalist Ellen Tordesillas’ question, “God, why did You give us President Rodrigo Duterte?” Watch and then join him in praying for our leaders and for our nation. 

Have you also asked God the same question? If you have, what made you ask? How did you resolve it? If not, why not? Post your comments, reactions, and prayer requests below using #TSCAReacts.

Visit our website to read more about Peter Kairuz's response: http://cbnasia.org/home/2016/10/god-give-us-president-rodrigo-duterte-peter-kairuz-answers/

Wikipedia;

Yellow journalism, or the yellow press, is a US term for a type of journalism that presents little or no legitimate well-researched
news and instead uses eye-catching headlines to sell more newspapers.[1] Techniques may include exaggerations of news events, scandal-mongeri
ng or sensationalism.
By extension, the term yellow journalism is used today as a pejorative to decry any journalism that treats news in an unprofessional or unethical fashion.[2]

The term is chiefly used in the US. In the UK, a roughly equivalent term is tabloid journalism, meaning journalism characteristic of tabloid newspapers, even if found elsewhere (e.g. on television).

“
RJ Nieto was one of my most brilliant students in the University of the Philippines - Diliman, Quezon City, where he majored in Mathematics, while I was a professor at the Institute of Mathematics. I can really say that I have been there all throughout his formative years in his becoming a mathematician par excellence. Indeed, he was verily one of my most brightest students. Although he didn't have as much of a head start in college compared to his peers, especially coming from a provincial high school as compared to his peers coming from prestigious schools in Metro-Manila, he however managed to excel by hard work and dogged determination so as to top above and over all of his classes. As a very fast learner, he is someone who can easily understand even very complex and challenging concepts, and simply them as like to water them down in to something that everyone else among his peers can understand to their low level. Also, it is very rare for a math major to be a member of the university debating team, which involves in debates, not just inside, but also outside the university. Actually, he was the only one who managed to do it even as a mathematics major gifted with such impeccable and perspicacious logic. His mind doesn't to work like anybody else. He is hardworking and so determine to excel in any field of endeavor that he can find himself interested and involved in! I remember that time when he enrolled in an elective Molecular Biology and Biotechnology (MBB) class under a visiting professor from Ludwig-Maximili
ans-University-
Munich of Germany. He had very little background in Biology and Chemistry. But he did extensive research and even sat down in biology classes to learn to catch up on the many strange and mindboggling jargons in MBB. I can say that it was as if he majored in and learned Biology in a just month. He even ended up acing the course, even above and over his classmates who were majors in the course. That is, he did so much better than his classmates who were MBB majors themselves. This somehow shows that RJ is not just a mathematician, but a polymath at that to learn diverse and desparate topics in a short and fast time!!! When he works, he does not settle for just a mediocre "good enough." Instead, he makes sure that everything he does is better than what he last works did. This is something that I really admire about this young man. He is a genius who should be honed to pursue more excellence.
”
Augusto Hermosilla

Share of Info lang about FakeNews: CONSIDER THE SOURCE: Click away from the story to investigate the site, its mission and its contact Info. CHECK THE AUTHOR: Do a quick search on the author. Are they credible? Are the real? CHECK THE DATE: Reposting old news stories doesn't mean they're relevant to current events. CHECK YOUR BIASES: Consider if your own beliefs could affect your judgement. READ BEYOND: Headlines can be outrageous in an effort to get clicks. What's the whole story? SUPPORTING SOURCES?: Click on those links. Determine if the info given actually supports the story. IS IT A JOKE? If it s is too outlandish, it might be satire. Research the site and author to be sure. ASK THE EXPERTS: Ask a librarian, or consult a fact-checking site. Well, only the fanatics and trolls never admit this....

comments.comment_text: Ganda naman diyan maam ellen
Talaga, Cez Donasco. Ang ganda. It's so elegant, Solong-solo ko ang pool.
Carlo Figueroa, you should include Baku in your travel plans. The city is soooo beautiful.
How long are you staying there maam ellen? Ganda! Pangmayaman ang pool! Hehe
Cez Donasco, I'm back. We stayed there for six days. Part of the Election observers group. You should introduce Baku to your prospective clients.

Baku is a city, capital of Azerbaijan, formerly part of the Soviet Union. Azerbaijan's neighbors are Russia, Iran, Armenia, Georgia. They produce oil and gas and they seem to be using their money intelligently, if one is to base it from the way Baku is developed.It's a modern city but has lots of character. It's fascinating history is well preserved.
Four Seasons is a very. very good hotel. Their beddings are heavenly!
Len, how does one get to Baku? How can one get a visa?:)

Hi Carlo, We went via Qatar (9 hours) then from Doha, 2 hours and 30 minutes to Baku. Gad, Carlo you will love Baku. Do you know that Azerbaijan money is subsidizing the Nobel Prize? The old home of the Nobels there has been turned into a museum but we were not able to visit. No time. They also subsidize the Barcelona football team. Our visa was in the form of a Migration Letter because we don't have a consulate there. I suppose a visa can be acquired that way. Sana manalo ako sa lotto para makabalik doon.
Wow. Sounds interesting. Sige, will research more about it.:)
View from my room at night where the Flames Tower (Fairmont Hotel) can be seen.
Another view from my room, day time.
Beautiful! Hoping I can visit it someday
Grabe naman, pang triathlon na swimming skills mo. Parang gusto ko na tuloy i-stop gym ko at mag swimming na lang. Thanks sa souvenir.
Ellen Tordesillas ikaw pala yung nag swimming? Akala ko ksi si Christine Reyes yun :)
Hehehe ...Alex Avisado Jr
love it :)
Ay naku Zaneth Zan Tafalla Lago sabihin mo kay Mader, i-project ang Baku. Hanap tayo story doon.
Anne de Bretagne, you are in Belgium, right? How many hours to Belgium or France from Azerbaijan?

They said aviation (airline and airport) is one area where they still have to catch up with developed countries. With their vast resources and young, educated, cosmopolitan population, give them 3 to 5 years and I bet they would be able to rival some of the old cities in Western Europe.
I think of all the new countries, they are the most developed. The city's urban design has a touch of Paris. I guess among the experts helping them are from France.
Next yr Ellen let's go visit amb. Victoria Bataclan and Anne de Bretagne habang mura pa ticket sa PAL.
Yes to London. Paris to begin next year. Even KLM is reasonably priced now.

I understand the Nobel Family's foundations esp the Nobel Sustainanility Trust are helping in the development of Azerbaijan, naking sure that it's environment-fri
endly. Their vegetables are all organic. Coming from a country where everything is helter-skelter,
I'm really awed by Baku.
U$D1,052. One way is about U$D400+.
Hanep. Lakas pala ng stamina mo, Ellen.
Dapat lang sa food trip ba naman na ginawa namin.
Ay gusto ko po yan! Panalo

However, investors of Kapa and other fast money or investment schemes have to understand that these firms are illegal in the eyes of the law. The Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) has reiterated why these firms are illegal and violating the law. Among these violations include selling securities without a registration filed with and approved by SEC, which is in violation of Republic Act 8799 or the Securities Regulation Code.

Supporters of these kind of schemes claim that those who enter in these schemes are entering a risk. One of those risks is these firms operating in violation of laws that cover investment firms. They may call it donation or whatever terms they use but in the eyes of the law they are violators unless they have the proper documents to deal with securities.

Since they may be in violation of the law, one day the government will act on these and shut these down; rega,dless if these schemes have helped you or not. It is the reality you have to face.

If these investment schemes want to continue to operate, they have to legalize their operations. Not only having a business permit but if they are dealing with securities, then they will have to also follow the standards set by SEC and by the law that governs them.https://

If you guys can read the history you can see its all backed by factual events. Edsa ŕevolition was 17 years in the making from 1969 since the conception of constitutional convention that was held 1971. It started all that.
It was that event when Marcos tried all his effort to stay in power and change what was written in the 1935 constitution. It was 1971 when constitutional convention was held at nagkadayaan ng boto ng delegations in favor of Marcos. When the people learn through expose' that Imelda bribed some of the delegates nagkagulo. Bombing of plaza miranda and other demonstrations happened and Marcos was given the reason to declare Martial Law and finally he could stay in power through military control! 10 years he closed major media outlets. A day after declaration he ordered arrest of the opposition without warrants 8,000 including senators, students, artists and many civillians were arrested imprisoned tortured, murdered and some exciled. videos.description:
#February23 #todayinhistory People Power Revolution, Day 2. #kasaysayan

Sa mga pilit nagtatanong — opo, andun po ako. College na ako noong 1986. Pero hindi po kailangan anduon; para pag-aralan ang history.  May primary at secondary sources na ginagamit ang mga istoryador. 

For enrichment:
-"Bayan Ko! Images of the Philippine Revolt" (Project 28 Days, Ltd., Hong Kong 1986, co-published in the Philippines by Veritas Publications and Communications Foundation, Inc.)
-"Breakaway" by Cecilio T. Arillo (CTA & Associates, Metro Manila, May 1986)
-"Ferdinand E. Marcos: Malacañang to Makiki" by AFP Col. Arturo C. Aruiza (ACA Enterprises, Quezon City. 1991)"Impossible Dream" by Sandra Burton (Warner Books, Inc., New York. 1989)
-"In Our Image" by Stanley Karnow (Random House, Inc., New York. 1989)
-"Nine Letters" by Cynthia Sta. Maria Baron and Melba Morales Suazo (Gerardo P. Baron, New Manila, Quezon City. 1986)
"On the Scene" by Asuncion David Maramba. (Solar Publishing Corporation, Philippines, 1987)
-"People Power" by Monina Allarey Mercado (Reuter Foundation, Metro Manila, 1986)
-"People Power" by Patricio R. Mamot (New Day Publishers, Quezon City. 1986)
-"Quartet of the Tiger Moon" by Nick Joaquin (Book Stop, Inc., Metro Manila. 1986)
-"The Marcos Dynasty" by Sterling Seagrave (Harper and Row, New York. 1988)
-"Worth Dying For" by Lewis M. Simons (William Morrow and Company, New York. 1987)
-http://edsarevolution.com/chronology/day2.php

Business Day
-"Claims on strength conflict". 24 Feb 1986.
-"Crowds stop Marcos tanks". 24 Feb 1986.

Malaya
-"Cory to FM: Leave!" by Larry Sipin and Ellen Tordesillas. 24 Feb 1986.
-"Cory urged to set up new govt". 24 Feb 1986.
-"Enrile rejects amnesty". 24 Feb 1986.
-"Nameless heroes of the hour" by Richie Benavides. 28 Feb 1986.
-"Radio Veritas transmitter destroyed". 24 Feb 1986.
-"Reagan doubts Marcos govt legitimacy". 24 Feb 1986.

Manila Times
-"Keithley’s longest night" by Jack M. Teotico. 3 Mar 1986.
-"Ramos Forms Army; New Forces For Cory" by Sheila Coronel. 2 Mar 1986.
-"A Rebellion that Defied All the Rules" by Sheila Coronel. 2 Mar 1986.

Mr. & Ms.
-"Cory’s love affair with the Filipino People" by Hilarion M. Henares. 7-13 Mar 1986.
-"How great little lives went to war" by Margie Ongkeko-Abrera. 21-27 Mar 1986.

Philippine Daily Inquirer
-"Attempt to knock Radio Veritas off the air" by M. Dizon. 24 Feb 1986.
-"Cory rallies behind Ramos-Enrile group" by Belinda Olivares Cunanan. 24 Feb 1986.
-"Enrile moves to Crame" by Fe Zamora. 24 Feb 1986.
-"Enrile tells his story". 16 Mar 1986.
-"Enrile to Cory: Take over Presidency" by Rey Arquiza. 24 Feb 1986.
-"FM sets govt. troops’ stance". 24 Feb 1986.
-"Majority of PC commands backing Ramos, Enrile?". 24 Feb 1986.
-"The new government starts jelling" by Belinda Olivares-Cunanan, 26 Feb 1986.
-"No to amnesty —Enrile" by Joey Nolasco. 24 Feb 1986.

Time
-"Anatomy of a Revolution" by William E. Smith. 10 Mar 1986.

Times Journal
-"Reagan tells FM to resign". 25 Feb 1986.

videos.description:
VERA Files founder Ellen Tordesillas first raised such concern during the joint hearing of the Senate committees on Justice and Human Rights and Public Information and Mass Media on Senate Bill No. 1296, which seeks to outlaw the creation and dissemination of fake news by amending the Republic Act No. 10175, or the Cybercrime Prevention Act of 2012, to accommodate the definition of “fake news” and add it among those considered a content-related offense.

Read more: https://inq.news/DropTheTermFakeNews
videos.title: Senators told: Drop the term ‘fake news’ in legislation

It Lola oh meaning nang news

What is news?? According to Wikipedia NEWS - is information about current events. Journalists provide news through many different media, based on word of mouth, printing, postal systems, broadcasting, electronic communication, and also on their own testimony, as witnesses of relevant events.

and ito pa Lola meaning nang information..

INFORMATION- facts provided or learned about something or someone.

SHARE- post or repost (something) on a social media website or application.

Journalist po ang tawag sa nag papakalat nang INFORMATION through NEWS...,

Ang tanong PAANO NAGIGING FAKENEWS ang isang NEWS..?

Ito Lola panawnaw ko Kung paano nagiging fakenews ang isang news...:

* Kung kulang, putol o pinutol o pinutol putol information nang source nang isang balita o NEWS... Example when the president say " if you do drug and destroying my country I will kill you..., But the journalist news that the president say "I will kill you".

*When the journalist twisted the information of the source to her or his NEWS.

* when the journalist NEWS the wrong information or data of the source..., Example real data of the source are 100 deaths but the journalist news it 1000 death..

But wrong data or information of the source is not a fakenews when the journalist use the word "according to" or
"ayon Kay" and "ayon SA"
Example the journalist news the situation and he or she says like this " according to Karen Davila Senator trililing is dead. But in real is not. The information of the source of the news is wrong but its not fake news kasi nag babalita lang ang journalist kung ano ang sinabi ni Karen Davila...

God, Why Did You Give Us President Rodrigo Duterte?

Peter Kairuz answers journalist Ellen Tordesillas’ question “God, why did You give us President Rodrigo Duterte?” Watch and then join him in praying for our leaders and for our nation. 

Have you also asked God the same question? If you have, what made you ask? How did you resolve it? If not, why not?

credit: The 700 Club Asia

videos.description:
HOW FIDEL V. RAMOS WON AGAINST A POPULIST IN 1992

The 1992 election was marred by vote-buying and allegations of fraud Ilke dagdag- bawas (vote-padding and shaving). According to columnist Luis D Beltran, "the COMELEC gun ban removed 'guns' from the triumvirate of guns, goons, and gold which have ruled Philippine election for decades, but 'gold' seems to have taken up the slack of effectiveness lost in banishing terrorism. The charges of vote-buying and massive expenditure are heard all over the land and it appears that Greed has replaced Fear as a major factor in the outcome of any election in die future." Allegations of fraud marred the election of Aquino's anointed successor, Fidel V Ramos. Ramos won with 24% of the votes in a race with six other presidential candidates. Presidential contender Miriam Defensor-Santiago trailed close with 20% of the votes. Santiago asserted that she was a victim of the "Sulo Hotel Operations" that manipulated the shaving and adding of votes to her disadvantage" Named after the hotel where the post-election operation was supposedly carried out, the group was responsible for the "dirty election tricks" that sealed Ramos's victory. In a December 14, 1993 letter by civic action group KILOSBAYAN to the COMELEC, the group raised the issue of unauthorized government funds released for post- election operations to ensure the victory of the administration's candidate, Fidel Ramos. A petition filed by KILOSBAYAN showed evidence that 70 million pesos was released by the Department of Budget and Finance soon after the May 11, 1992 elections to a private entity called the Philippine Youth, Health and Sports and Development Foundation headed by veteran campaign strategist Ronaldo Puno. Philippine Star columnist Teodoro Benigno also alleged that Ronaldo Puno was a key member of the Sulo Hotel Operations. Like most corruption and fraud cases, finding evidence to verify the activities of the widely-rumored Sulo Hotel Operations was impossible. Years later, an interview with former Ramos political adviser Jose Almonte was asked about the difference between the election protest of Santiago in 1992 and the protest of the opposition against Arroyo in 2005. His reply: "there was no tape." Almonte was referring to the lack of evidence in 1992. In Almonte's memoirs he recounted the Sulo Hotel Operations: "I gathered all, if not most, of the known election operators or the experts in cheating. I assembled them in one group….I asked how much each was paid for his service. I asked for the average reasonable fee and agreed to pay them the amount they quoted. Each one operated independently."

The case against Sulo Hotel Operators never flourished because of lack of evidence. Yet occasionally there are those who slip and acknowledge that they were part of it. Years later, a political operator who worked for the Ramos candidacy was interviewed by investigative journalist Ellen Tordesillas. In charge of special operations, his job was to "employ both legitimate and illegitimate means... it is a necessary evil in every campaign. The one who carries special operations is referred to as a political operator. That's what I am. The operator had this to say about the 1992 elections:

"In 1992, we encouraged the candidacy of Imelda Marcos because she was taking votes of Marcos loyalists from Cojuangco. Unknown to her, we provided the audience for her rallies to make her believe she had a large following. But I wasn't part of the so-called Sulo Hotel Operations of Ronnie Puno that many believe was the dirty tricks department of Lakas (Ramos' party) in the '92 campaign. That was actually a post-election operation, although it existed before elections. It had fifteen day lifetime that was spent waiting for the proclamation of the election winner.

The Sulo Hotel operators claim that they were instrumental in the victory of FVR, but I believe their role was more of ensuring that FVR accumulates a comfortable lead over Miriam Defensor Santiago."

It did not also help that Santiago had no money and machinery compared to all other candidates (throughout the campaign she mostly relied on her youth volunteers) to protect her early lead in the elections. Furthermore, another disadvantage that she faced was that the political party she established, the People's Reform Party, was only accredited the day before the election.

Santiago was leading the canvassing of votes for the first five days. Following a string of power outages, the tabulation concluded, and Ramos was declared president-elect. Santiago filed a protest before the Supreme Court as electoral tribunal, citing the power outages during the counting of votes as evidence of massive fraud. Her election protest was eventually dismissed on a technicality by the Presidential Electoral Tribunal that she was already a senator.

In an article by Teddy Locsin, a supporter of '92 presidentiable Ramon Mitra, he recounted how the cheating went:

Election day came. The votes came in. Mitra sank lower and lower in the count. But in ABS-CBN’s quick count—a super exit poll, not extrapolating from samplings but communicating the count as it was being made—Miriam got vote after vote after vote, Aparri to Jolo. Then, for a reason Commission on Elections never explained, the ABS-CBN quick count was blacked out. Suitcases stuffed with papers poured into Greenhills. Two weeks later the quick count was allowed to resume to show Miriam losing. After the winner was proclaimed, the young were inconsolable. So Miriam made many appearances in schools. This one was in Santo Tomas.

We walked with her down the corridor leading to the auditorium. We heard clapping from the classrooms. At first a smattering of applause, but quickly more and more of it. Soon the corridor was reverberating with claps and cheers. It reached a crescendo when the doors to the auditorium opened and a blast of cheers and applause hit us in the face. Cries of a hurricane force, conveying grief with the result, disgust with democracy, and total contempt for the voting process washed over us like bile.

Miriam walked to the podium. The air was electric with energy. She turned to the audience and bowed. Pandemonium broke lose. She did not say a word. They had said it all for her. That evening, in the long corridor past the morgue and in that hall, democracy died the death it deserved. Women in the media gloated: Well, better that “that” woman was cheated than she became president.
videos.title: The Political Career of Miriam Defensor Santiago

Aplikante sa Senado | Susan Ople 

Kilala bilang takbuhan ng Overseas Filipino Workers (OFWs) at anak ng dating senador na si Blas Ople, sumalang si Susan "Toots" Ople sa iba't ibang katanungan hinggil sa kontraktwalisasyon at kapanatagan sa trabaho ng mga Pinoy. Tutol ang kandidato sa pagkasenador sa diumano'y kawalan ng "economic roadmap" ng gobyerno na dahilan ng pangingibangbayan ng marami nating kababayan. Panoorin ang panayam sa kanya nina Luchi Cruz-Valdes, Atty. Mel Sta. Maria at Ellen Tordesillas.

videos.description:
Have you asked the same question?

“God, why did you give us President Rodrigo Duterte?”

It is a fact that the unanimous majority voted for our current President Duterte. Whether we like it or not, we are supposed to support and pray for him and all the elected or appointed leaders of the country.

The current issues concerning our President and his endorsement of killing people involved in drugs and the illegal drug trade, the words that come out of his mouth, and the image that he and the Philippines now bear raises a lot of questions. One of which is journalist Ellen Tordesillas’ asking God “why did you give us President Rodrigo Duterte?”

Isn’t it a valid question?

Here’s CBN Asia’s Peter Kairuz responding. Will you take some time to listen and pray with us?

http://cbnasia.org/home/2016/10/god-give-us-president-rodrigo-duterte-peter-kairuz-answers/

Alamin ang turo ng kasaysayan. Malaya ang mamamayan kung may kalayaan sa pamamahayag. Pakikiisa sa mga kaibigan at kasamahan sa industriya.  #DefendPressFreedom #Fyt!

(In this video, journalists from the martial law period all the way to today’s campus reporters stand up to demonstrate the Philippines’ enduring commitment to the defense of press freedom. This video was co-directed by Jason C. Tan and Paolo Villaluna, with cinematography by Dindo Martinez and Franz Lopez. It was written and produced by Patricia Evangelista.)

Edith Burgos Luis V. Teodoro Ellen Tordesillas Ceres P Doyo Melinda Quintos De Jesus Inday Espina-Varona Jun Sepe Cheche Lazaro Maria Ressa Jes Aznar Ces Drilon Carlo Gabuco JC Gotinga Barnaby Lo Pia Ranada Robles Rambo Talabong Christian Deiparine Flint Osric Teves Gorospe Michelle Abad

videos.description:
"Nandito tayo ngayon to build our capacity to figure out the truth and to tell those truths to power to our readers to our audience" - Glenn Omanio

Ang pagsusulat ay umuusbong kahit saan, ito'y kagamitan pandigma laban sa hindi patas at 'di-makatotohanan. Siyang tunay, na nahanas ang isipan ng manunulat mula sa Ang Madyaas at The Madyaas ng Antique National School, sa gabay ni Gng. Rhodbe Penaflorida Pandoy . Sa gayon, naging makabuluhan ang idinaraos na 𝗦𝗲𝗺𝗶𝗻𝗮𝗿 𝗪𝗼𝗿𝗸𝘀𝗵𝗼𝗽 𝘀𝗮 𝗣𝗮𝗺𝗮𝗺𝗮𝗵𝗮𝘆𝗮𝗴 𝗣𝗮𝗻𝗴𝗸𝗮𝗺𝗽𝘂𝘀 kasama ang Vera Files at natatangi nitong manunulat at mamahayag, na pinamumunuan ni Ginang Ellen Tordesillas. Higit rin ang aming pasasalamat kay GInoong Glenn Omanio na nagbigay daan at ilaw sa pamamagitan ng pag-isponor upang maisakatuparan ang kaganapang ito. Sa muli, Salamat guid kaninyo tanan !

videos.description:
Sultan’s daughter, Princess Jacel Kiram, explains why Sabah is for the Philippines

The issue on the West Philippine Sea has been in frequent talks for several years now. However, that region is not everything that the Philippines has a historical claim on for certain areas. We must not forget that somewhere in Mindanao, there was once a great sultanate in Sulu and their royal house, their lineage, can help us remember another region that the Philippines has a historical claim on: Sabah.

This interview can help us get educated on the general ideas on why Sabah is historically owned by the Philippines and not by Malaysia. There are countries that have been teaching their children, through schools and forms of media, on the reasons why certain territories are theirs and why they have more rights in certain areas than other countries. In the Philippines, we hope that our government, schools, communities, and families would do a better job in educating our people on the territories that we have been claiming for decades now.

It is a privilege that I was able to interview the Princess Jacel Kiram–daughter of the late Sultan Jamalul Kiram III–who has clear direct blood ties with the former sultans of Sulu.

Princess Jacel Kiram raised the following points:

1.    Sabah is producing an income of $72B per year. If we are going to compute that, how much can it help to benefit the Filipino people?

2.    Sabah is a property owned by the sultanate of Sulu. But because Sulu is officially part of the Philippines, a constitutionally republican-democratic country, then Sabah is also part of the Philippines.

3.    The Philippine claim for Sabah goes back to the 1700’s. It was given to sultanate of Sulu by the sultanate of Brunei as a token of gratitude in helping to stop the rebellion in Brunei.

4.    The sultanate of Sulu rented Sabah to British North Borneo Company. The agreement was it would pay 5,000 Mexican gold coins per year. However, when Malaysia was born in the 1960’s and the British turned over the authority to Malaysia for their country, Malaysia continued the rent. But, instead of paying through Mexican gold coins, they paid through the amount of 5,300 ringgit per year. Today, one ringgit costs less than P13. Imagine how low this is compared to the income caused by Sabah of $72B per year. This is why the sultanate of Sulu would rather cancel the rent, have the whole of Sabah be back under full operations of the Philippines, and help make the Filipinos benefit from it completely once again.

5.    Actually, when the sultanate of Sulu made moves to get Sabah back in 2013, the Malaysian government already stopped paying their annual rent because they wanted to show that Sabah is indeed theirs so why do they pay rent? Still, it cannot be denied that they have been paying rent for decades now and it was only because they wanted to show they’re not “renting” it which is why they stopped paying even if there is a rental agreement.

6.    In 2016, President Duterte had a clear stand on Sabah. He said that it is for the Filipinos. We are hoping that our government would successfully push for it, using a lot of political will to get Sabah back for Filipinos.

***************************

The following is not anymore part of the interview and Princess Jacel Kiram did not say this, but the blogger intends to write it down anyway to give more context on this issue:

President Duterte has not made a strong political move to advance the Philippine case for Sabah, although Miriam Defensor-Santiago was trying to do so when she was alive. She wrote some of her notes in her 2015 International Law book published by Rex Bookstore.

The following are notes from 2016 that may still need to be continually verified and observed even today out of caution:

There have been rumors that the Malaysian government has been funding some Filipino politicians so that they would not help the Kiram family and the Filipinos in claiming Sabah back. The funding may be in the form of P10 million or business deals. Names like Governor Hataman would surface as part of the beneficiaries of the Malaysian government. (See references below).

There are also those saying that the recently passed Bangsamoro Organic Law, previously known as the Bangsamoro Basic Law (BBL), was done through the funding of Malaysian government. Not all stakeholders were included in the discussion and has a clear say in the distribution of powers.

There are those who support the narrative that the people in Mindanao, the Moros, were never part of the Philippines as they were just forced to be part of it. This claim runs in contradiction to the acknowledgement of the sultanate of Sulu and other royal clans that they acknowledge they have been part of the Philippines for so long now, and there have been candidates from the Muslim Filipino in our national and local elections, even producing lawyers, who all swore allegiance to protect our constitution, sovereignty, and our laws as they serve the people.

There were fears that with the passage of the Bangsamoro Organic Law, that it would help in erasing the memory and hold of the royal families, thus resulting to the eventual loss or weakening of claim of territories such as Sabah. There were attempts by Malaysia to buy Sabah, but the late Sultan Jamalul Kiram III always refused even if there were leaders in the Philippine government urging him to accept the offer. Who else is very strong and consistent in claiming it, educating people about it, and seriously putting it in their platforms aside from the royal families who have a stake in it?

The new leaders would then produce their own “democratic” dynasties, and Malaysia funding other people who have royal blood to assert royal titles, thereby creating confusion on who is the real titleholder of what sultanate. It is a sad thing that historical titles, traditional authorities, sovereignty, and claims might be set aside, forgotten, or be funded against in the pretext of establishing more democratic institutions. Also, there were legislators who told me that they only voted in favor of the Bangsamoro Organic Law out of fear of the president or as a party agenda, though it is not clear that they won’t try to become independent of the Philippines.

Although, the Philippine government really has to do a lot of helping out for those living in Mindanao. People in Luzon and Visayas should have more heart or compassion for those in Mindanao, because we are one people.

I wrote this down so as that the leaders and advocates of this new political system would prove themselves otherwise, and that---hopefully---the Filipinos from Luzon, Visayas, and Mindanao would always find a common cause to stay together and fight not with each other but for each other.

There are also people in Sabah whose hearts we have to win.

References:

Adilah, Anith. (2018). Malaysia backs Philippines’ Bangsamoro Organic Law. Retrieved on January 5, 2018 from https://www.malaymail.com/s/1656952/malaysia-backs-philippines-bangsamoro-organic-law

Avecilla, Victor. (2015). Malaysia’s vested interests in the BBL. Retrieved on January 5, 2018 from http://manilastandard.net/news/bangsamoro-basic-law/172905/malaysia-s-vested-interests-in-the-bbl.html

Jannaral, Julmunir I. (2018). ARMM gov accepts leadership fellowship in Malaysia. Retrieved on January 5, 2018 from https://www.manilatimes.net/armm-gov-accepts-leadership-fellowship-in-malaysia/445651/

Pareño, Roel. (2018). ARMM ready for Bangsamoro transition – Mujiv Hataman. Retrieved on January 5, 2018 from https://www.philstar.com/headlines/2018/03/05/1793622/armm-ready-bangsamoro-transition-mujiv-hataman

Politiko Mindanao. (2018). Gov. Hataman completes short-term course in Malaysia. Retrieved on January 5, 2018 from https://mindanao.politics.com.ph/gov-hataman-completes-short-term-course-in-malaysia/

Romero, Jose V., Jr. (2018). MILF-Malaysian ties and the BBL. Retrieved on January 5, 2018 from https://www.manilatimes.net/milf-malaysian-ties-bbl/379521/

The Manila Times. (2018). Explain Malaysia’s role in the Bangsamoro agreement. Retrieved on January 5, 2018 from https://www.manilatimes.net/explain-malaysias-role-in-the-bangsamoro-agreement/220188/

Tordesillas, Ellen, T. (2015). Magdalo Rep: Malaysia’s role in creation of Bangsamoro still cause of concern. Retrieved on January 5, 2018 from https://news.abs-cbn.com/blogs/opinions/06/27/15/magdalo-rep-malaysias-role-creation-bangsamoro-still-cause-concern
videos.title: Sultan’s daughter, Princess Jacel Kiram, explains why Sabah is for Filipinos

videos.description:
As one of the activities lined up for the CAC Week on March 20-24, 2023, the College of Arts
and Communication invites members of the UP Baguio Community to the Marshall McLuhan
Forum Series on Responsible Media (please refer to the attached poster).

This installment of the Marshall McLuhan Forum is cohosted by the Department of
Communication with the Embassy on Canada. It features McLuhan fellows and nationally
recognized journalists Christian Esguerra, Ellen Tordesillas, and Manny Mogato.

The forum will be held at the Teatro Amianan on March 24, 2023 (Friday) from 9am to 12nn.
The event will also be livestreamed at the CAC Dap-ay grounds and via the CAC Facebook page
for viewers who cannot be accommodated in the venue.

For questions and clarifications, please reach out to Prof. Orville B. Tatcho, Chair of the Dept. of
Communication.
videos.title: College of Arts and Communication UP Baguio Live Stream -- Marshall McLuhan Forums 2023

videos.description:
We are going to have ginataang labong(tambo in kinaray-a) wd baog (dried dilis), saluyot (tugabang) and okra for lunch.

Those who grew up  in the barrio know what Nang Ludying, our house companion, is doing.We even have a riddle related to it: Ginsakyan ang kabayo,naga-andar. Pero wara paghalin. (The horse has been mounted.He's on.But he does not move.) Ano ri-a? (What is it?)

Enjoy the rest of the holidays.

"ANC: DOON SA VERY BASIC MUNA, ELLEN, ANO ANG WORKING DEFINITION NG "FAKE NEWS"?

ELLEN (VERA FILES): (STAMMERS)... WALA KASING DEFINITION...

ANC:  WORKING DEFINITION.

ELLEN:  FALSEHOOD... (STUTTERS) WHAT WE TRACK ARE, UHM, FALSEHOOD THAT APPEARS IN WEBSITES AT ARE BEING SHARED IN FACEBOOK

ANC:  KASI, IN SOME LITERATURES, BASICALLY THERE ARE 2 ELEMENTS, PERO SYEMPRE DEBATABLE PA, THERE ARE 2 ELEMENTS. UNTRUE AND FABRICATED, IF YOU ASK ME, BAKA DAPAT SIGURO IDAGDAG ANG ISSUE NG MALICIOUS INTENT, WHICH IS VERY HARD TO PROVE"
